statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: BYU 74, Wyoming 68
article.story: LARAMIE, Wyo. (AP) -- Offensive rebounding. That's how Wyoming coach Steve McClain summed up his team's loss to BYU on Saturday afternoon. The Cougars out-rebounded the Cowboys 45-34, including pulling down a season-high 20 offensive boards, on their way to a 74-68 victory. "It showed that we had determination today by the rebounding numbers. Wyoming is a great rebounding team, and we were able to outrebound them by 11," said BYU coach Dave Rose. "We made an effort to limit Wyoming to one shot, and we worked on that in practice." The strong rebounding effort from the Cougars resulted in 16 second-chance points, compared with just six by Wyoming. "Really that's what hurt us in the first half," McClain said. "We had trouble with transition defense, and we had trouble with rebounding the basketball." "That's the hardest thing to defend is when you give up an offensive rebound and now they throw it back out," McClain said. "Those are the ones that are killers because you can't get back there. It's gonna be a wide-open shot, and they've got too good of shooters. Even though they didn't make many threes, they made crucial ones." BYU shot 46.2 percent from beyond the 3-point arc, hitting 6-of-13 attempts. Jimmy Balderson scored six of his 11 points during an 11-4 run that gave BYU (16-7, 8-4 Mountain West) a 65-62 lead with 5:36 remaining. The Cougars made five of their final six free throw attempts, while Wyoming (12-14, 5-8) was just 2-of-8. "If we make our free throws, the game unfolds all right for us," McClain said. Wyoming struggled from the outside, hitting just two of 14 3-point attempts. "I thought that a big part of the game was Wyoming's shooting problems from the perimeter," Rose said. "We were able to get a hand in their face and make it difficult to see the rim." Jackson Emery added 13 points for BYU, followed by Trent Plaisted with 12. Emery, who had not scored in his last six games for BYU, shot 4-6 from the field, including hitting three three-pointers. "Jackson (Emery) had a great game for us," Rose said. "He always works hard, and he is a big reason why we were able to jump to a lead in the first half." Brandon Ewing led Wyoming with 25 points and Brad Jones scored 11. Justin Williams had eight points, 13 rebounds, and a career-high 11 blocked shots, tying the school's single-game record. "I thought he (Williams) was out there battling as hard as he could. He had his hands on a million balls and blocked 11 shots. I'm not sure you can ask any more out of him," McClain said. With his 25 points, Wyoming's Ewing set a new Mountain West Conference freshman scoring record in conference play. His 200 points in conference games broke the previous record of 182 held by Andrew Bogut of Utah. BYU led 43-35 at halftime, after closing the period on an 8-3 run. Emery hit back-to-back 3-pointers during an 8-0 BYU second-half run that gave the Cougars their biggest lead of the game at 53-43. But Wyoming countered with a 15-1 run that gave the Cowboys a 58-54 lead midway through the second half. With the win, BYU has now won six of its last seven games, while the Cowboys have lost six of their last seven. Five of the Cowboys' losses have been decided by less than 10 points, and three of them by two points or less. "At some point, one of them's going to go our way," McClain said. "Maybe a ball will bounce our way one time, or a ball will lay on the rim and go in instead of going out. Those are things that have haunted us for a while."
